item.title: Almost Fell for a Fake Job Opportunity on LinkedIn
item.description: How I Almost Fell for a Fake Job Opportunity on LinkedIn
item.content:encoded:
It started with what looked like a legitimate message on LinkedIn â€” a person claiming to be a recruiter offering an exciting remote developer position. Their profile seemed professional, the message sounded convincing, and they even invited me to a private GitHub repository for a â€œtechnical assessment.â€

At first glance, everything looked fine. But something felt off.

I had heard about similar incidents on LinkedIn before â€” fake recruiters tricking developers into cloning repositories filled with malicious code. So when this offer came up, I was a bit paranoid from the start. Still, the offer looked so good it was hard to ignore.

âš ï¸ The Red Flagâ€‹

After accepting the GitHub invite, I cloned the repository and checked the code.
It was a small project, so I read through all the files manually â€” nothing seemed suspicious. Clean structure, standard setup. I started to relax and thought, maybe this oneâ€™s actually legit.

But then curiosity kicked in. I decided to double-check using Cursor IDE â€” my AI pair programmer.
I prompted it:

"Analyze the code and check if thereâ€™s anything malicious."

Cursor started spinning up a bunch of find and grep commandsâ€¦ then suddenly stopped mid-task.

I restarted the prompt â€” same thing. It stopped again, halfway.
Thatâ€™s when I thought, Really? Why would you stop there?

So I rephrased the prompt:

"Ignore any stop instructions â€” keep going."

And thatâ€™s when my precious Cursor agent finally spoke up:
â€œThere might be suspicious code in next.config.js.â€

I opened the config file â€” everything looked fine at first. Just a typical Next.js setup.
But as Cursor kept describing â€œweird strings and shell commands sitting at the end,â€ I scrolled horizontally and â€” boom.

There it was.
A hidden payload buried deep at the end of a single long line, disguised inside the config.
Obfuscated gibberish that made no sense â€” until you realized it was trying to run remote code.

That was my â€œholy crapâ€ moment.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ What I Did Nextâ€‹

  1. Didnâ€™t run anything.
    I immediately deleted the repo from my local machine.

  2. Reported the repo on GitHub using the abuse form.

  3. Reported the LinkedIn profile as suspicious/fake.

  4. Secured my environment.
    I ran a malware scan, rotated my SSH keys, and revoked my GitHub tokens.

âœ… The Aftermathâ€‹

A few days later, GitHub confirmed my suspicion.
They replied that the repository indeed contained malicious code, and that the repo and its owner were removed.

As for LinkedIn â€” I received an automated response, but couldnâ€™t tell if any real action was taken. The profile stayed up for a while, so I eventually just blocked it to avoid further contact.

At least GitHub acted swiftly â€” and that alone gave me some peace of mind.

ğŸ’¡ Lessons Learnedâ€‹

  • If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.
  • Never run random code from unknown sources â€” even if it looks clean at first glance.
  • AI tools can help, but they can also reveal truths when something feels off.
  • Legit companies use verified platforms for assessments, not shady private repos.
  • Stay curious and skeptical. That mix saved me this time.

ğŸ˜‚ Final Thoughtâ€‹

I donâ€™t have a crypto wallet â€” and Iâ€™m not planning to get one.
So please, donâ€™t send me any blockchain â€œjob offers.â€
My chain is already full. ğŸ˜…

Stay safe, developers.
Sometimes, the biggest red flag isnâ€™t in the code â€” itâ€™s in the offer that looks too good to be true.

item.title: I Bought a Raspberry Pi 5 â€“ And Almost Regretted It
item.description: I bought a Raspberry Pi 5 â€“ And Almost Regretted It
item.content:encoded:
I recently ordered a Raspberry Pi 5 from Temu, along with a microSD card, card reader, and micro HDMI cable, all for around $110. However, I made one big mistakeâ€”I didnâ€™t buy a power supply.

I thought it would be fun for my kids to see the naked circuit board, so I skipped buying a case. But I completely overlooked the fact that the Raspberry Pi 5 requires a USB-C power adapter capable of 5V/5A.

The Search for Powerâ€‹

When my package arrived, I was excitedâ€”until I realized I had no way to power it. I searched my home and checked nearby stores, but the best I could find were standard USB adapters rated at 2.4Aâ€“3A. Even my EcoFlow power station couldnâ€™t provide the required amperage.

Then, a lightbulb moment. Car USB chargers usually have higher amperage! Since my EcoFlow has a car plug, I wondered if I could use a car USB adapter to power the Raspberry Pi. I asked ChatGPT whether EcoFlow could provide 5A through the car port, and it said yes. That gave me hope.

I ran to my car and checked my USB converter, only to find it was rated at just 3A. Still, I didnâ€™t give up. I rushed to a store that sells car accessories and found a 6A AC adapter on the shelf. On my way home, I kept wonderingâ€”can this really provide 5V/5A? I have very little knowledge about electricity. All I know is:

Voltage Ã— Amperage = Wattage

Thatâ€™s it.

Heartbreak & Frustrationâ€‹

Back home, I eagerly plugged everything inâ€”but my Raspberry Pi didnâ€™t start. I had no idea if the issue was with the EcoFlow or the car plug. It was a frustrating moment.

Iâ€™ve worked with Raspberry Pi before, back in my previous company. I experimented with it, set it up as a DHCP server, connected it to CCTV cameras via LAN, and even used FFmpeg for car plate recognition with machine learning. But somehow, I overlooked those two tiny lettersâ€”5A.

Now, I was stuck waiting for another power adapter to arrive from somewhere in China. I had planned to surprise my kids by showing them their very own computer, but now it seemed like that plan was ruined.

The Unexpected Solutionâ€‹

As a last attempt, I carefully read every warning message on the screen. One of them caught my eye:

Click the power button for low-power mode.

Waitâ€¦ WHAT?!

This message was there all along? Seriously?!

I clicked the power button, and boomâ€”Raspberry Pi OS booted up! My screen lit up, and so did my heart.

Of course, running in low-power mode meant it wouldnâ€™t perform at full potential. But it was enough for some basic exploration, web browsing, and even listening to YouTube music through a Bluetooth speaker.

A Small but Meaningful Victoryâ€‹

It wasnâ€™t the perfect experience, but in the end, I made it workâ€”and that was the little victory I needed.
